translation: Perhaps because Miho and Satsuki often meet in their hometown, they have similar expressions and ways of speaking.
Their way of eating sweets is particularly similar, both delicately breaking cookies into smaller pieces with their manicured hands before bringing them to their mouths.
I wonder if it's been like this since before, but when I try to recall, my memory is vague.
I sometimes think that the little habits and gestures of the two people we met before might have already flowed away somewhere.
Miho is now married and has bought a used single-family home in her hometown, where her friends often gather.

There are times when I dread having to work part-time again tomorrow, but it's my only connection with a world outside the convenience store, and a valuable opportunity to interact with other "average women in their thirties" like Miho.
Therefore, I try to accept Miho's invitations whenever possible.
Today, as always, Miho, Yukari with her small child, Satsuki who is married but without children and I got together.
We brought cakes to Miho's house and had tea.
At that moment, I was able to become a part of the world for the first time.
I thought I was born just now.
As a normal part of the world, I was indeed born on this day.
For the two weeks leading up to the opening, persistent practice continued with partners and staff acting as fictitious customers.
Look into the "customer's" eyes, smile and bow, put sanitary products into a paper bag, separate hot items from cold ones, and if asked for fast food, sanitize your hands with alcohol.
In order to get accustomed to handling money, the cash register was filled with real money, but the receipt had "Training" printed in large letters on it.
And since my counterpart was a part-timer like me wearing the same uniform, it kind of felt like we were playing pretend shopping.
My younger sister, unlike me, was a "normal" child.
But that didn't mean she shied away from me; on the contrary, she admired me.
When my sister was being scolded by our mother for something ordinary, unlike me, I approached my mother and asked, "Why are you angry?"
When the lecture from our mother ended due to the question I had asked, my sister always said "Thank you" to me, perhaps thinking she had been saved by me.
I wasn't really interested in sweets or toys, and often gave them to my younger sister.
Therefore, my younger sister was always following me around.
"Dad, because you like yakitori, let's grill and eat this today.
Wondering whether he had not heard me clearly, I repeated it in a distinct pronunciation.
My mother was surprised, and the other kid's mom next to her also seemed shocked as her eyes, nostrils and mouth all opened wide at once.
I almost laughed because of his strange face, but when I saw him staring at my hands, I thought, right, one is not enough.
"Should I get more?"
When I glanced at the sparrows walking in a row nearby, my mother, who finally came to her senses, shouted desperately in a scolding tone, "Keiko!"
"Let's make a grave for the little bird and bury it.
See, everyone else is crying too.
It's sad that our friend has passed away, isn't it?
"Hey, isn't it pitiful?"
"Why? Even though they're already dead. ..
At my question, my mother was left speechless.
Put canned coffee, cigarettes, and corn dogs into a small-sized bag quickly.
During that time, the man who had been jingling the coins in his pocket suddenly seemed to have an idea and put his hand into his breast pocket.
From that gesture, I instantly judge that they're going to make the payment with electronic money.
"Welcome, good morning!"
With a slight bow, I take the canned coffee offered by the male customer.
"Ah, and one of the number five cigarettes," "Understood.
I quickly pull out a Marlboro Light Menthol and scan it at the register.
"Please touch for age verification.
While touching the screen, he sees the man's gaze smoothly shift to the fast food lined up in the showcase, and stops his finger movements.
"Would you like something?"
I always offer, but when the customer seems undecided about making a purchase, I step back and wait.
I turn around in response to the faint sound of loose change, diverting my gaze towards the cash register.
People who jingle coins in their hands or pockets are often those who are looking to quickly buy cigarettes or a newspaper and return home, so they are sensitive to the sound of money.
Sure enough, there was a man approaching the cash register with a can of coffee in one hand and the other hand stuck in his pocket.
Quickly move around the store and slip into the cash register counter, standing inside so as not to keep customers waiting.
The convenience store is filled with sound.
The sound of the chime as customers enter, the voice of an idol promoting new products over the store's public address system.
The sound of scanning barcodes, accompanied by the clerk's calling out.
The sound of items being placed in the basket, the sound of a bread bag being clenched, and the sound of heels walking around the store.
Everything mixes together, becoming the "sound of the convenience store," constantly touching my eardrums.
